taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Inhabits freshwater rivers, lakes and reservoirs, frequenting areas with a lot of submerged branches, such as flooded forests (Ref. 12693).  Adult fish feed on small shrimps, fish fry and small fishes while young individuals take zooplankton  (Ref. 6459).  Also feeds on crabs, worms and insect larvae (Ref. 12693) and plants (Ref. 56749).  Esteemed food fish which is marketed fresh and often seen in aquarium trade (Ref. 12693).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Asia:  Chao Phraya basin, Mekong basin of mainland Southeast Asia, Kapuas basin in western Borneo and Musi basin in Sumatra (Ref. 10425).  Protected in Thailand (Ref. 12217).
dataObjects.references: Roberts, T.R. and M. Kottelat 1994 The Indo-Pacific tigerperches, with a new species from the Mekong basin (Pisces: Coiidae). Ichthyol. Explor. Freshwat. 5(3):257-266. (Ref. 10425)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.description: 45.0 cm SL (male/unsexed; (Ref. 7050)); max. published weight: 10,000 g (Ref. 9497)
references: Kottelat, M., A.J. Whitten, S.N. Kartikasari and S. Wirjoatmodjo 1993 Freshwater fishes of Western Indonesia and Sulawesi. Periplus Editions, Hong Kong. 221 p. (Ref. 7050)
Roberts, T.R. 1993 Artisanal fisheries and fish ecology below the great waterfalls of the Mekong River in southern Laos. Nat. Hist. Bull. Siam Soc. 41:31-62. (Ref. 9497)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: Has the deepest body of any species of Coius, 2.1-2.4 times in SL.  Specimens from mainland Southeast Asia invariably with five full bars, specimens from Borneo with 6-7 bars, all usually continued across ventral surface of body.  First bar extending uninterrupted and undiminished across opercle and onto thoracic region, and continued across ventral surface of body; a well defined black mark on ventral surface of body immediately anterior to base of pelvic fins (not present in other Coius).  Partial bars almost invariably absent.  Branched dorsal rays 14-18; branched anal rays 9-11, usually 10 (Ref. 10425).

dataObjects.subject: http://www.eol.org/voc/table_of_contents#Wikipedia
dataObjects.title: Datnioides microlepis
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: "Datnioides microlepis." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 9 Mar 2014, 17:47 UTC. 29 Dec 2014 <http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Datnioides_microlepis&oldid=638323294>.
dataObjects.description:
Datnioides microlepis (common names: Indonesian tiger datnoid, or Indo Datmoid or Indonesian tigerfish or finescale tigerfish) is a species of freshwater fish endemic to the Chao Phraya River basin in Thailand, the Mekong River basin, the Kapuas River basin in Borneo, and the Musi River basin in Sumatra.[1] This fish is commonly seen in the aquarium trade, and often are seen when juvenile (3-4 inches). This fish grows up to 18 inches in the wild, but does not attain this size in aquaria(12 inches). A minimum 100 gallons is required to house this fish its whole life.

References[edit]

  1. ^ "Datnioides microlepis (Bleeker, 1854)". FishBase. Retrieved 6 October 2013.
